Welcome to this wonderful example timeline.

1,000 years from now

Natural phenomenon due to which tidal locking occurs

Due to the lunar tides decelerating the Earth's rotation, the average length of a solar day will be 1⁄30 SI second longer than it is today. To compensate, either a leap second will have to be added to the end of a day multiple times during each month, or one or more consecutive leap seconds will have to be added at the end of some or all months.[12]

  • Tidal acceleration
  • Solar day
  • International System of Units
  • [12]

1,100 years from now

Periodic change in the direction of a rotation axis

As Earth's poles precess, Gamma Cephei replaces Polaris as the northern pole star.[13]

  • Precession
  • Gamma Cephei
  • Polaris
  • Pole star
  • [13]

10,000 years from now

If a failure of the Wilkes Subglacial Basin "ice plug" in the next few centuries were to endanger the East Antarctic Ice Sheet, it would take up to this long to melt completely. Sea levels would rise 3 to 4 metres.[14] One of the potential long-term effects of global warming, this is separate from the shorter-term threat to the West Antarctic Ice Sheet.

  • Wilkes Subglacial Basin
  • East Antarctic Ice Sheet
  • Sea level
  • [14]
  • Long-term effects of global warming
  • West Antarctic Ice Sheet

10,000 – 1 million years from now

Stars with a supergiant luminosity class with a spectral type of K or M

The red supergiant stars Betelgeuse and Antares will likely have exploded as supernovae. For a few months, the explosions should be easily visible on Earth in daylight.[15][16][17][18][19]

  • Red supergiant star
  • Betelgeuse
  • Antares
  • Supernova
  • [15]
  • [16]
  • [17]
  • [18]
  • [19]

11,700 years from now

Brightest star in the constellation Lyra

As Earth's poles precess, Vega, the fifth-brightest star in the sky, becomes the northern pole star.[20] Although Earth cycles through many different naked eye northern pole stars, Vega is the brightest.

  • Vega
  • List of brightest stars
  • Pole star
  • [20]
  • Naked eye

11,000–15,000 years from now

Angle between the rotational axis and orbital axis of a body

By this point, halfway through Earth's precessional cycle, Earth's axial tilt will be mirrored, causing summer and winter to occur on opposite sides of Earth's orbit. This means that the seasons in the Southern Hemisphere will be less extreme than they are today, as it will be facing away from the Sun at Earth's perihelion and towards the Sun at aphelion, while the seasons in the Northern Hemisphere, which experiences more pronounced seasonal variation due to a higher percentage of land, will be more extreme.[21]

  • Axial tilt
  • Summer
  • Winter
  • Southern Hemisphere
  • Perihelion and aphelion
  • Perihelion and aphelion
  • Northern Hemisphere
  • [21]

15,000 years from now

Hypothesis about migration of species between Africa and Eurasia

According to the Sahara pump theory, the oscillating tilt of Earth's poles will move the North African Monsoon far enough north to change the climate of the Sahara back into a tropical one such as it had 5,000–10,000 years ago.[22][23]

  • Sahara pump theory
  • Axial tilt
  • North African Monsoon
  • Sahara
  • Neolithic Subpluvial
  • [22]
  • [23]

17,000 years from now

Volcano that has erupted 1000 cubic km of lava in a single eruption

The best-guess recurrence rate for a "civilization-threatening" supervolcanic eruption large enough to eject one teratonne (one trillion tonnes) of pyroclastic material.[24][25]

  • Supervolcanic
  • Pyroclastic material
  • [24]
  • [25]

25,000 years from now

Polar water ice deposits on Mars

Mars' northern polar ice cap could recede as Mars reaches a warming peak of the northern hemisphere during the c. 50,000-year perihelion precession aspect of its Milankovitch cycle.[26][27]

  • Martian polar ice caps
  • Mars
  • Apsidal precession
  • Milankovitch cycle
  • [26]
  • [27]

36,000 years from now

Dim, low mass stars on the main sequence

The small red dwarf Ross 248 will pass within 3.024 light-years of Earth, becoming the closest star to the Sun.[28] It will recede after about 8,000 years, making first Alpha Centauri (again) and then Gliese 445 the nearest stars[28] (see timeline).

  • Red dwarf
  • Ross 248
  • [28]
  • Alpha Centauri
  • Gliese 445
  • [28]
  • List of nearest stars and brown dwarfs

1,000 years from now

Experimental nuclear-powered US Air Force satellite

The SNAP-10A nuclear satellite, launched in 1965 to an orbit 700 km (430 mi) above Earth, will return to the surface.[156][157]

  • SNAP-10A
  • [156]
  • [157]

3183 CE years from now

Work of public art by Manfred Laber

The Zeitpyramide (time pyramid), a public art work started in 1993 at Wemding, Germany, is scheduled for completion.[158]

  • Zeitpyramide
  • Wemding
  • Germany
  • [158]

2,000 years from now

Maximum lifespan of the data films in Arctic World Archive, a repository which contains code of open-source projects on GitHub along with other data of historical interest, if stored in optimum conditions.[159]

  • Arctic World Archive
  • Open-source
  • GitHub
  • [159]

10,000 years from now

Deep geological repository for radioactive waste

The Waste Isolation Pilot Plant, for nuclear weapons waste, is planned to be protected until this time, with a "Permanent Marker" system designed to warn off visitors through both multiple languages (the six UN languages and Navajo) and through pictograms.[160] The Human Interference Task Force has provided the theoretical basis for United States plans for future nuclear semiotics.[161]

  • Waste Isolation Pilot Plant
  • Official languages of the United Nations
  • Navajo language
  • Pictogram
  • [160]
  • Human Interference Task Force
  • Semiotics
  • [161]

10,000 years from now

American nonprofit organization

Planned lifespan of the Long Now Foundation's several ongoing projects, including a 10,000-year clock known as the Clock of the Long Now, the Rosetta Project, and the Long Bet Project.[162]

Estimated lifespan of the HD-Rosetta analog disc, an ion beam-etched writing medium on nickel plate, a technology developed at Los Alamos National Laboratory and later commercialized. (The Rosetta Project uses this technology, named after the Rosetta Stone.)

  • Long Now Foundation
  • Clock of the Long Now
  • Rosetta Project
  • Long Now Foundation
  • [162]
  • HD-Rosetta
  • Focused ion beam
  • Los Alamos National Laboratory
  • Rosetta Stone

10,000 years from now

Globally accessible seed bank on Spitsbergen, Svalbard, Norway

Projected lifespan of Norway's Svalbard Global Seed Vault.[163]

  • Svalbard Global Seed Vault
  • [163]

10,000 years from now

American astronomer and astrophysicist (1930–2022)

Most probable estimated lifespan of technological civilization, according to Frank Drake's original formulation of the Drake equation.[164]

  • Frank Drake
  • Drake equation
  • [164]

10,000 years from now

Spread of world views, products, ideas, capital and labour

If globalization trends lead to panmixia, human genetic variation will no longer be regionalized, as the effective population size will equal the actual population size.[165]

  • Globalization
  • Panmixia
  • Human genetic variation
  • Effective population size
  • [165]

20,000 years from now

According to the glottochronology linguistic model of Morris Swadesh, future languages should retain just 1 out of 100 "core vocabulary" words on their Swadesh list compared to that of their current progenitors.[166]

  • Glottochronology
  • Morris Swadesh
  • Swadesh list
  • [166]

24,110 years from now

Time for exponential decay to remove half of a quantity

Half-life of plutonium-239.[167] At this point the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, the 2,600-square-kilometre (1,000 sq mi) area of Ukraine and Belarus left deserted by the 1986 Chernobyl disaster, will return to normal levels of radiation.[168]

  • Half-life
  • Plutonium-239
  • [167]
  • Chernobyl Exclusion Zone
  • Ukraine
  • Belarus
  • Chernobyl disaster
  • [168]
